instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with liquid damage primarily in <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> area. Replaced <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> and all affected components. When turned on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> are fluctuating drastically including <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>. stuck at 5V on charger.

What should be checked next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
1. The rails on these machines usually cycle when there is a short somewhere. Post Resistance to GND values on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. 

2. Do you have steady 5v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Remove F7000 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6912</CAPACITOR> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
5v is not steady on meter

Resistance to GND <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.580  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 1.2  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 10.30 million


Fuse removed

<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>   12.36v

<CAPACITOR>C6912</CAPACITOR> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 10.30 million"
Do you mean short to ground, when F7000 is in place?

"Fuse removed
<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>   12.36v"
Good enough, because of missing <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>...
"<CAPACITOR>C6912</CAPACITOR> 0v"

Post <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> voltages.
Use surrounding components as test points.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
No short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> .400 diode mode with fuse in place



PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3HRTC flucuates .700V to 0V

P3V3G3HRTC_PHASE1  fluctuates from .200V to 0V

P3V3G3HRTC_PHASE2 fluctuates from .200V to 0V

P3V3G3HRTC_PGOOD fluctuares .600V to 0V

P3V3G3HRTC_FB FLUCTUATES .200v TO 0v

<SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> flucuates 2.2V to 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Sorrry, I forgot this is T2 board.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> MUST appear first; is the "mother" of all voltages, including <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

"Resistance to GND ... <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 10.30 million " (miliohm to ground???)
----------------
No short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> .400 diode mode"
Can you clarify this???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> also is fluctuating however it is stable at 12.36V if <RESISTOR>R6907</RESISTOR> is removed

Yes no short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> .400 diode is correct

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Then replace <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>.
Seems that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> only drops when <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> tries to appear.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>/35 and check if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Yes <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present and steady with  <RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>/35 removed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C6912</CAPACITOR> voltage?

"Resistance to GND <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.580"
What's that, ohm, Kohm?
Post diode mode (red probe at ground) on pad1/<RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C6912</CAPACITOR> 11.05V

it was ohms

0.0001 diode on  pad1/<RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<CAPACITOR>C6912</CAPACITOR> 11.05V"
More than needed to fry T2, CPU and god knows what more  :(.
Check <RESISTOR>R6912</RESISTOR>/13 values (ohm mode).

So you have short on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
I hope you understand the need of posting correct/useful information now.

You can use voltage injection method, to find the culprit.
Take your time and read the forum, if you are not sure how to.
If is not T2/CPU, you can spend some more time with this board.
However, MUST get correct <CAPACITOR>C6912</CAPACITOR> voltage, before resolder <RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>/35!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
When injecting voltage looks like <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is getting warm. Is this chip possible to replace? 

Set power supply to 3V at 5amps. Put positive wire on pad 1 of <RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Read more about voltage injection on the forum.
If not, you can risk to fry something in the future!

Remove <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and check if short gone.
If yes, replace the chip.
Not sure if have board specific firmware.
Just in case, take one from donor, same model board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Can you send link on what to read for injectuing voltage in situations like this? Always thought it was as simple as injecting the power into the rail unless its <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and in that case check the mosfets first.


where do you get donars for this model? I haven't had any luck finding them

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Start injecting with 1V and increase slowly, if needed; do not exceed 4V.
Set amp limit to max on the PSU first.

Getting T2 scrap board is really dificil...
